              Home / Academics / Master of Social Work / Curriculum / Field Learning                                                               Student Manuals and Forms                                                                                                                                                                                 Student Manuals   The purpose of the Manuals is to acquaint you with the School's procedures and requirements so that you can succeed in your studies. Consult the School's web site and your email for updates.     Undergraduate Field Learning Manual (PDF)     MSW Student Manual (PDF) (includes Field Learning materials)     Fields of Practice and Focused Learning Opportunities (PDF)   Field Placement Process & Timeline Advanced Concentration Year (PDF)     Checklist Field Placement Process Advanced Concentration Year (PDF)   Informational Meetings - Focused Learning Opportunities and Fields of Practice (PDF)     Student Field Placement Web Forms   Login with your University ‘Albert’ NetID and Password: Field Placement Web Forms     Your information on ‘Albert’ such as program, address, and contact information appears on the web forms and cannot be modified on the form. If required, please modify your information on ‘Albert’. These updates will automatically update our Field Learning database. For assistance please call the Office of Field Learning and Community Partnerships at (212) 998-5920.     Employment based field learning applications and guidelines:     Extended One Year Residence (OYR) / 900 Hours Application (PDF)     Extended One Year Residence (OYR) Guidelines (PDF     Employment based (Non-OYR) / 600 Hours Application (PDF)     Employment based (Non-OYR) Guidelines (PDF)       Student Evaluation Forms   The assessment of students in field is based upon the CSWE Core Competencies. The field instructor, in collaboration with the student, works to evaluate the student’s progress over the course of the year.   Initial Educational Statement   The Initial Educational Statement should be completed by the field instructor and student collaboratively. Part I, the Orientation and Field Instruction Plan, should be completed within the first two weeks of placement. Part II provides a baseline assessment of the student’s skill level, establishes the learning plan for the remainder of the semester, and provides an initial indication of the grade level of the student’s performance in the early stages of placement. Part II should be completed in the 7th week of field placement.     Undergraduate Senior Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Professional Foundation Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Advanced Concentration Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Advanced Concentration Initial Educational Statement / Micro Macro Practice (PDF)     Mid-Year Evaluation   The Mid-Year Evaluation is completed at the end of the first semester of either the foundation year or the advanced concentration year and after the student has finished the 300 hours required for field instruction. The field instructor completes the evaluation in collaboration with the student, and the evaluation signed by both. The faculty advisor reviews the evaluation as a major component of assigning a grade for Field Instruction. (The faculty advisor will not be able to give a grade without a completed evaluation).   Final Evaluation   This evaluation is completed at the end of the second semester of either the foundation or advanced concentration placement, after the student has finished the additional 300 hours required for Field Instruction (and a total of 600 hours for each of the foundation and advanced concentration placements). The field instructor completes the evaluation in collaboration with the student, and the evaluation signed by both. The faculty advisor reviews the Final Evaluation as a major component of the process of assigning a grade for Field Instruction II or IV. (The faculty advisor will not be able to give a grade without a completed evaluation.)     MSW Professional Foundation Mid-Year & Final Evaluation (PDF)   MSW Advanced Concentration Mid-Year & Final Evaluation (PDF)     Undergraduate Senior Mid-Year & Final Evaluation (PDF)   Undergraduate Junior Final Evaluation (PDF) (After completion of 100 hours)       Form Instructions: Save a copy of the PDF form(s) to your computer prior to completing the evaluation form. The field instructor and student should both sign the evaluation form. The evaluation can be scanned and emailed to field.learning@nyu.edu or and faxed to (212) 995-4533. Evaluations can also be hand delivered or mailed to:     NYU Silver School of Social Work  Office of Field Learning & Community Partnerships  One Washington Square North  New York, NY 10003   For assistance please call the Office of Field Learning & Community Partnerships at (212) 998-5920. Graduate Application Guide                Home    Application Guide    Financial Aid    Tuition and Cost of Attendance    Housing    Events    Study Abroad    Admitted Students                                     Special Instructions for All International Applicants            1. Apply On Time    Because additional mailing time and processing are required for international credentials, you should have all application materials in our office by the appropriate application deadline.    2. Transcripts and Degree Information    You must have the equivalent of a U.S. bachelor's degree to be considered for admission. Candidates holding an artist diploma may be considered for the music performance, music theory, or composition programs. For each post-secondary school attended, one (1) transcript in the original language and one (1) notarized English translation are required to be submitted with your application. In determining what items to submit, please understand that the Admissions Committee must be able to review four elements related to your prior studies: (1) the courses taken as part of your studies; (2) the grades received for those courses; (3) the actual degree/title conferred and (4) the date the degree was confered/awarded.    Due to accrediting and internship requirements, applicants to the M.S. in clinical nutrition (HOND) who have non-U.S. credentials must present a course-by-course evaluation of their international credentials along with their completed application. A number of agencies can provide this service.       Locate an independent foreign degree evaluation agency       3. Proficiency in English    The ability to communicate effectively in English is crucial to your success as an NYU Steinhardt student. Our goal is to ensure our international graduate candidates are successful in their academic program and in any fieldwork they must complete, therefore, all candidates are assessed using a two-stepped approach :    Step 1: The graduate application using TOEFL    The Test Of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) is mandatory for all applicants whose native language is NOT English and who did not receive the equivalent of a 4 year U.S. undergraduate education from an institution where English is the official language of instruction. Applicants holding or completing a graduate degree from an English speaking institution are still required to submit a TOEFL if their graduate education was LESS THAN four years in duration at an institution where English was the official language of instruction. The TOEFL cannot be waived.    Although we do not have a required TOEFL score, successful applicants score 100 or above on the Internet-based test or 600 or above on the paper-based test.    If you are required to submit a TOEFL score, you must submit your score in two formats :          An official TOEFL score report must be sent to NYU Steinhardt from ETS. NYU Steinhardt's ETS institution code is 2556 ; a departmental code is not required. Visit TOEFL’s Website .    A copy of your TOEFL Score must be uploaded into the online application under the "TOEFL Upload" section. Since this is an unofficial report for informational purposes only, web printouts or screenshots are acceptable for the upload as long as we can read the scores and your name.          Note: NYU Steinhardt does not accept scores from other equivalent exams such as IELTS.    Step 2: Post-admission assessment using NYU ALI English Language Proficiency Exam    If you are offered admission to NYU Steinhardt you will be required to take the online English Proficiency Exam at NYU’s American Language Institute (ALI) . A fee is charged on the day of the exam (phone number: 212-998-7040; ali.test-group@nyu.edu ).    You may be exempted from the exam if English is your first language or if you graduated from a college or university where English was the language of instruction. Having submitted the TOEFL score during the application process does not exempt you from the ALI English Proficiency Exam. Obtaining a specific score on the TOEFL also does not exempt you from taking the exam. Your academic department may require the exam regardless of your English proficiency.    Candidates who must take the ALI English Proficiency Exam will receive their results after they complete the two-part exam. Results of the exam are used as an additional tool to assess English language abilities beyond the TOEFL. In some programs, where English language skills are especially critical, students are expected to comply with ALI recommendations. In other programs where English language skills are less essential to beginning study, our faculty and advisors use the ALI recommendations to make individual determinations about the need for additional English language study in accordance with the demands and expectations of the program, student’s career goals, and fieldwork and clinical settings.    Based on your level of achievement on the TOEFL and the ALI English Proficiency Exam, the rigors of your program you may be required to take additional English coursework at NYU ALI during your first semester. Please note that English-language study may increase the overall cost and time to completion of your degree program.    4. Financial Aid    NYU Steinhardt encourages international applicants to investigate scholarship support offered by their home country to support their studies at NYU.    Master's and advanced certificate applicants who are not U.S. citizens or permanent residents are not eligible for federal financial aid and typically do not receive consideration for school-based financial aid.    Full-time doctoral applicants, regardless of country of citizenship, will receive consideration for scholarships, fellowships, and assistantships.    5. Visa Information    Once admitted international applicants will apply for an I-20 to receive an F1 student visa with their acceptance package. Financial documentation will be necessary when applying for a visa. Financial documents should NOT be submitted with the application for admission.    All international applicants wishing to obtain an F1 student visa will list "New York University" as the "expected visa sponsor" on the graduate admissions application. When completing your application, please be sure to use your full, legal name as it appears on your passport. The use of any other names, such as nicknames, will cause serious delays in applying for your U.S. visa. All international applicants must have an international address as their permanent address. The U.S. government mandates that you include a permanent, international address to receive your visa.    Please be prepared to pay additional fees for processing your I-20 from NYU and your student visa from the U.S. government. Heightened security measures may result in delays in processing your I-20 and your student visa requests. Please apply for these credentials as soon as possible, using overnight and express mail wherever possible. More information is available post-admission via the Office of Global Services Pre-Arrival web page .
